reverse.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to change something, such as a decision, judgment, or process so that it is the opposite of what it was before
reverse.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The decision was reversed on appeal.
More changes are required to reverse the trend towards centralised power.
reverse.translation[0].definitions[1].de: if a vehicle or its driver reverses, they go backwards
reverse.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Bob reversed into a parking space.
I reversed the car into a side road.
reverse.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to change around the usual order of the parts of something, or the usual things two people do
reverse.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Our roles as child and guardian had now been reversed.
reverse.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to turn something over or around, in order to show the back of it
reverse.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Reverse the paper in the printer.
reverse.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: The Supreme Court reversed the decision.
He spoke in favor of the bill, reversing his previous position.
She is pressing the government to reverse its policy.
Immigration has increased sharply and reversing this trend will be extremely difficult.
His policies had reversed the decline in the economy.
We cannot reverse the ageing process.
Hair conditioner canâ€™t reverse the damaging effects of colouring and perming.
reverse.translation[1].definitions[0].de: the position of the gears in a vehicle that makes it go backwards
reverse.translation[1].definitions[1].de: a defeat or a problem that delays your plans
reverse.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Losing the Senate vote was a serious reverse for the president.
reverse.translation[1].definitions[2].de: the less important side or the back of an object that has two sides
reverse.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: The British ten-pence coin has a lion on the reverse.
reverse.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to change something such as a decision, judgement, or process so that it is the opposite of what it was before
reverse.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: Will the government reverse its decision to lower oil prices?
The California Supreme Court reversed a lower court ruling that blocked a resort hotel from being built.
The company had been struggling to reverse huge losses.
reverse.translation[3].definitions[1].de: to develop or do something in the opposite way to before
reverse.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: Bond prices abruptly reversed direction and fell.
The President reversed course and cut a deal with Congress.
reverse.translation[3].definitions[2].de: to make a telephone call which is paid for by the person you are telephoning
reverse.translation[4].definitions[0].ex: U.S. law on this matter is virtually the reverse of British law.
reverse.translation[4].definitions[1].de: a defeat or problem that delays your plans
reverse.translation[4].definitions[1].ex: Losing the Senate vote was a serious reverse for the President.
reverse.translation[5].definitions[0].de: used to describe something that is the opposite of something else
reverse.translation[5].definitions[0].ex: Last year, we had a lot of supply and not much demand. But this year we had the reverse situation.
